# A Proofs 

Proofs that did not appear in the main text are detailed here.
Proposition 2. A matching $\mu$ is unanimous on $L$ if and only if it is efficient on $L^{\prime}=$ $\left(M,>_{I},>\right)$.

Proof. We first prove $(\Longrightarrow)$, that is, if $\mu$ is unanimous on $L$ then it is efficient on $L^{\prime}$. Suppose, for a contradiction, that this is not true. This would imply that $\mu$ is unanimous on $L$, but $\mu$ is not efficient on $L^{\prime}$. If $\mu$ is not efficient on $L^{\prime}$, then there exists some sequence $\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \ldots, c_{n}\right)$ such that for all $i \neq n$, (i) $\mu\left(c_{i+1}\right) \geq_{I\left(c_{i}\right)} \mu\left(c_{i}\right)$, (ii) either $\mu\left(c_{1}\right) \geq_{I\left(c_{n}\right)} \mu\left(c_{n}\right)$ or $h \geq_{I\left(c_{n}\right)} \mu\left(c_{n}\right)$ for some $h$ with $\mu(h)=\varnothing$, and (iii) this must hold strictly for at least one $i$. Consider the matching $\mu^{\prime}$ such that the (possibly cyclic) trades implied by the sequence above occur. For any $c$ such that $\mu(c)=\mu^{\prime}(c)$, we have that $c \in I^{*}(\mu) \Longleftrightarrow c \in I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ and $c \in \kappa(\mu) \Longleftrightarrow c \in \kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$. For any $c^{\prime}$ such that $\mu\left(c^{\prime}\right) \neq \mu^{\prime}\left(c^{\prime}\right)$, we have that $\mu^{\prime}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \geq_{I\left(c^{\prime}\right)} \mu\left(c^{\prime}\right)$, so:

$$
c^{\prime} \in I^{*}(\mu) \Longrightarrow \mu\left(c^{\prime}\right) \in H^{*}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \Longrightarrow \mu^{\prime}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \in H^{*}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \Longrightarrow c^{\prime} \in I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)
$$

the following also holds:

$$
c^{\prime} \in \kappa(\mu) \Longrightarrow \mu\left(c^{\prime}\right) \neq \varnothing \Longrightarrow \mu^{\prime}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \neq \varnothing \Longrightarrow c^{\prime} \in \kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)
$$

For at least one $c^{\prime \prime}: \mu^{\prime}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)>_{I\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)} \mu\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)$. We have that either $\mu\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right) \notin I^{*}(\mu)$ or $\mu\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)=\varnothing$. We also have that if $\mu\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right) \notin I^{*}(\mu)$, then $\mu\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right) \in I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$. If $\mu\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)=\varnothing$, then $\mu^{\prime}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right) \neq \varnothing$. These facts imply that either $I^{*}(\mu) \subset I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ or $\kappa(\mu) \subset \kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$, i.e., $\mu$ is not unanimous, a contradiction.

Next, we prove $(\Longleftarrow)$, that is, if $\mu$ is efficient on $L^{\prime}$ then it is unanimous on $L$. Again, suppose, for a contradiction, that $\mu$ is efficient on $L^{\prime}$ but that it is not unanimous on $L$. Since $\mu$ is not unanimous, there exists some $\mu^{\prime}$ such that either (a) $I^{*}(\mu) \subset I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ and $\kappa(\mu) \subseteq \kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ or (b) $I^{*}(\mu) \subseteq I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ and $\kappa(\mu) \subset \kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$. Without loss of generality, we denote the set $S$ and $S^{\prime}$ as $I^{*}(\mu)$ and $I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ if (a) holds, alternatively, $\kappa(\mu)$ and $\kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ if (b) holds. First, note that if $\mu^{\prime}(c)=h$ for some $c \in S^{\prime}$ such that $c \notin S$ and $h$ with $\mu(h)=\varnothing$, then we can construct a third matching $\mu^{\prime \prime}$ where $\mu^{\prime \prime}(c)=h$ and $\mu^{\prime \prime}=\mu$ otherwise. The above relations give us that $\mu^{\prime \prime}(c)>_{I(c)} \mu(c)$ and $\mu^{\prime \prime}\left(c^{\prime}\right)=\mu\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ for all $c^{\prime} \neq c$, so $\mu^{\prime \prime}$ Pareto dominates $\mu$ on $L^{\prime}$, contradicting efficiency. Therefore, for any $c$ satisfying the stated conditions, it must be that $\mu^{\prime}(c)=h$ for some $h$ such that $\mu(h) \neq \varnothing$. We can construct a sequence $\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \ldots, c_{n}\right)$ such that $c_{1}=c$ and $c_{i}=\mu\left(\mu^{\prime}\left(c_{i-1}\right)\right)$ for $i \neq 1$. By unanimity of $\mu^{\prime}, \mu\left(c_{i}\right)=\mu^{\prime}\left(c_{i-1}\right) \geq_{I\left(c_{i-1}\right)} \mu\left(c_{i-1}\right)$ for $i \neq 1$ and $\mu\left(c_{2}\right)=\mu^{\prime}\left(c_{1}\right)>_{I\left(c_{1}\right)} \mu\left(c_{1}\right)$. Yet, if $\mu$ is efficient on $L^{\prime}$, then no such sequence described can be constructed, a contradiction. This proves the Proposition.

Proposition 4. Unanimous Top Trading Cycles is constrained-efficient and unanimous.
Proof. Unanimity follows because for any $c \in I^{*}\left(\mu^{1}\right), c$ can only participate in a cycle or chain such that $c$ would be matched to some $h \in H^{*}(c)$. A similar conclusion holds for every $c \in \kappa\left(\mu^{1}\right)$. Unanimity of $\mu^{1}$ directly implies unanimity for $\phi_{U T T C}$.

Next, we demonstrate that UTTC is constrained-efficient. Suppose, for a contradiction, that it is not. There must exist some $\mu^{\prime}$ such that $\phi_{U T T C} \triangleright_{P D} \mu^{\prime}$. Since $\phi_{U T T C}$ is unanimous, $\mu^{\prime}$ cannot (a) weakly expands the set of unanimous children and matched children and (b) strictly so for one of the two sets. Therefore, $I^{*}\left(\phi_{U T T C}\right)=I^{*}\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)$ and $\kappa\left(\phi_{U T T C}\right)=\kappa\left(\mu^{\prime}\right) . \phi_{U T T C} \triangleright_{P D} \mu^{\prime}$ implies that we can identify some Pareto improving cycle or chain $\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \ldots, c_{n}\right)$ such that every $c_{j}$ in the cycle satisfying $c_{j} \in I^{*}\left(\phi_{U T T C}\right)$ is reallocated to a unanimous home.

Consider the earliest child $c_{i}$ in the cycle to be removed from the UTTC algorithm. If $c_{i} \in I^{*}\left(\phi_{U T T C}\right)$, then $\phi_{U T T C}\left(c_{i+1}\right) \in H^{*}\left(c_{i}\right)$. Since $c_{i}$ was removed, this implies that $c_{i}$ was not pointing at $c_{i+1}$. Further, because $\phi_{U T T C}\left(c_{i+1}\right) \in H^{*}\left(c_{i}\right)$ we know that it must be the case that $c_{i+1}$ was removed in an earlier round. This contradicts our assumption that $c_{i}$ was the earliest to be removed. If $c_{i} \notin I^{*}\left(\phi_{U T T C}\right)$, the same contradiction is immediate because $c_{i}$ 's pointing is only restricted to unanimously acceptable homes. Therefore, no such cycle or chain can exist, and $\phi_{U T T C}$ cannot be Pareto dominated by a matching that weakly expands the set of unanimous and matched children. This proves the Proposition.

Theorem 1. The following statements are true:
i. Linear Exchange is incontestable.
ii. Linear Exchange is weakly unanimous.

iii. Any weakly unanimous matching that Pareto dominates Linear Exchange is unanimously dominated by Linear Exchange.

Proof. We will say that $c$ u-prefers $h$ over $h^{\prime}$ if $h>_{I(c)} h^{\prime}$ and $c$ prefers $h$ over $h^{\prime}$ if $h \succ_{c} h^{\prime}$. First, we show that the algorithm produces a weakly unanimous matching. Suppose, for a contradiction, that $\phi_{L E}$ is not weakly unanimous. Note first that if $h \notin H^{k}$ for some round $k$, then $h \notin H^{k^{\prime}}$ for any $k^{\prime}>k$ as if a child is unmatched from a home, another child is matched to that home. Suppose that $h>_{I(c)} \phi_{L E}(c)$ for some $h$ with $\phi_{L E}(h)=\varnothing$. Let $i$ be the round when $c$ exits the exchange. If $h \in H^{*}(c)$, then it cannot be that $c$ exited the exchange in this round. Hence, $h \in H^{-}(c)$ and $\phi_{L E}(c)=\varnothing$. However, this implies that $h$ was a tradable home for $c$. Hence, there exists some $c^{\prime} \notin C^{i}$ such that $h>_{I\left(c^{\prime}\right)} \phi_{L E}\left(c^{\prime}\right)$. Similarly, at round $i^{\prime}$ when $c^{\prime}$ left the exchange, $c^{\prime}$ only leaves if $h \notin H^{*}\left(c^{\prime}\right)$. Hence, $h \in H^{-}\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ and $\phi_{L E}\left(c^{\prime}\right)=\varnothing$. We can consider the first $c^{\prime \prime}$ that exits the exchange and u-prefers an unmatched home. As we showed above, there must be another child that exited the exchange earlier with no match and u-prefers the same unmatched home. This is a contradiction, therefore, no $c$ u-prefers an unmatched home over $\phi_{L E}(c)$.

This implies that $\phi_{L E}$ must contain a SU-cycle. Let $\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \ldots, c_{n}\right)$ be this SU-cycle. Note that since all children u-prefer the following child's home, it must be that $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{j}\right) \in$ $H^{-}\left(c_{j}\right)$ for all $c_{j}$ in the cycle. Hence, any child in the cycle must exit the exchange in some round. Consider the last $c$ in the cycle that exits the exchange in some round i. $\mu^{i+1}(c)=\phi_{L E}(c)$ only if no cycle would form as a result. This is a contradiction. Therefore, $\phi_{L E}$ cannot contain a SU-cycle.

Next, we prove, by strong induction, that $\phi_{L E}$ is not Pareto dominated by any other weakly unanimous matching $w$ that $\phi_{L E}$ does not unanimously dominate. Denote $c^{n}$ as the $c$ choosing in round $n$. Our induction statement is this: in any round $n$, for any $c, h$ such that:

1. $c \notin C^{n}$,
2. $h$ is unanimously acceptable to $c$, and
3. $h \succ_{c} \mu^{n}(c)$
then, for any weakly unanimous matching $w$ with $w(c)=h$, we have $\mu^{n}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \succ_{c^{\prime}} w\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ for some $c^{\prime} \neq c$.

Base case: $n=1$. The statement trivially holds since $C^{1}=C$.
Induction step: We assume that the statement holds for all rounds $k \leq n$ and prove that it holds for round $n+1$. Note that if $c^{n} \in C^{n+1}$, the statement trivially holds, so we consider only rounds when $c^{n} \notin C^{n+1}$ and prove the statement by cases. Denote $\mathbf{h}$ as $c^{n}$ 's most preferred home in $H^{n}$.

Case 1: $\mu^{n+1}\left(c^{n}\right)=\mathbf{h}$. Since $\mu^{n+1}(c)=\mu^{n}(c)$ for all $c \notin C^{n}$, if (1)-(3) hold for $c$ in round $n$, then the statement must hold for $c$ in round $n+1$. We show it holds also for $c^{n}$. Clearly, (1) holds for $c^{n}$ in round $n+1$. Suppose (2)-(3) also hold for some $h^{\prime}$. We have:

$$
h^{\prime} \notin H^{n}
$$

Otherwise:

$$
h^{\prime} \succ_{c^{n}} \mathbf{h}
$$

which is a contradiction. Denote $c^{\prime} \equiv \mu^{n+1}\left(h^{\prime}\right)$. In any weakly unanimous matching $w$ with $w\left(c^{n}\right)=h^{\prime}, w\left(c^{\prime}\right) \neq h^{\prime}$. If $h^{\prime} \succ_{c^{\prime}} w\left(c^{\prime}\right)$, then we are done. Otherwise, since $w$

is weakly unanimous, $w\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ is acceptable to $c^{\prime}$. If $w\left(c^{\prime}\right) \succ_{c^{\prime}} h^{\prime}$, then, by the inductive assumption, there must exist another $c^{\prime \prime}$ such that $\mu^{n}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)=\mu^{n+1}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right) \succ_{c^{\prime \prime}} w\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)$.

Case 2: $\mu^{n+1}\left(c^{n}\right) \neq \mathbf{h} \Longrightarrow N T^{n}\left(c^{n}\right) \neq H^{n}$. As we demonstrated above, $c^{n}$ cannot improve to any $h^{\prime} \notin H^{n}$. Hence, if the statement does not hold, (2)-(3) must be true for some $h \in H^{n}-N T^{n}\left(c^{n}\right)$. However, in any weakly unanimous $w$ with $w\left(c^{n}\right)=h$, we must have that $w\left(c^{\prime}\right) \neq \mu^{n}\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ for some $c^{\prime} \notin C^{n}$. Otherwise, there would be a SU-cycle on $w$. If $\mu^{n}\left(c^{\prime}\right)=\mu^{n+1}\left(c^{\prime}\right) \succ_{c^{\prime}} w\left(c^{\prime}\right)$, we are done. If $w\left(c^{\prime}\right) \succ_{c^{\prime}} \mu^{n+1}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)$, then, by the inductive assumption, there must exist another $c^{\prime \prime}$ such that $\mu^{n}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)=\mu^{n+1}\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right) \succ_{c^{\prime \prime}} w\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)$.

Note that if $\phi_{L E}$ is Pareto dominated by any $w$, there must be a Pareto improving cycle $Y=\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \ldots, c_{m}\right)$ on $\phi_{L E}$ where $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{j+1}\right) \succsim_{c} \phi_{L E}\left(c_{j}\right)$ for all $j \neq m$ and $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{1}\right) \succsim_{c_{m}}$ $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{m}\right)$ with at least one strict relation. (There may also be a chain where $c_{m}$ 's Pareto improving home is vacant. This case is ruled out by ruling out cycles, so we do not write it explicitly.) By the induction above, any Pareto improving cycle $Y$ that maintains weak unanimity (and unanimous acceptability) cannot involve any $c$ such that $c \notin C^{n}$ for any $n$. Any $c_{k} \in Y$ must satisfy $c_{k} \in C^{n}$ for all $n$, so $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{k}\right) \in H^{*}\left(c_{k}\right)$. Let $w$ be the weakly unanimous matching implied by executing the trades on $Y$. Consider the $c_{j}$ that chooses in the earliest round $i$ such that all other children in the cycle choose after $c_{j}$. Since $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{j}\right)$ is $c_{j}$ 's most preferred home in $H_{i}^{*}\left(c_{j}\right), w\left(c_{j}\right) \succ_{c_{j}} \phi_{L E}\left(c_{j}\right) \Longrightarrow$ $w\left(c_{j}\right) \notin H_{i}^{*}\left(c_{j}\right)$. Additionally, $w\left(c_{j}\right) \in H^{i}$ since $Y$ only involves children remaining in the exchange. These facts imply that $w\left(c_{j}\right) \in H^{-}\left(c_{j}\right)$. Because $\phi_{L E}\left(c_{k}\right) \in H^{*}\left(c_{k}\right)$ for all $c_{k} \in Y, w$ is unanimously dominated by $\phi_{L E}$. Therefore, any such $w$ that Pareto dominates $\phi_{L E}$ must be unanimously dominated by $\phi_{L E}$, and there cannot exist a weakly unanimous $w$ that Pareto dominates $\phi_{L E}$ that is not unanimously dominated by $\phi_{L E}$.

Finally, suppose that $\phi_{L E} \triangleright_{P D} \mu$ for any feasible $\mu$. If $\mu$ is unanimous, then it is weakly unanimous. However, if it is weakly unanimous and Pareto dominates $\phi_{L E}$, then it is unanimously dominated, a contradiction. This proves the Theorem.

Theorem 2. The following statements are true:
i. Any unanimous matching mechanism is obviously manipulable.
ii. Serial Dictatorship with Indifference and Linear Exchange are non-obviously manipulable if $|H| \leq|C|$.

Proof. We prove (i) that any unanimous matching mechanism is obviously manipulable using an example. Consider the following market with $C=\{a, b\}$ and $H=\{1,2,3\}$. The preferences, evaluations, and induced unanimity orders for $b$ are as follows, where omitted homes are not unanimously acceptable and brackets indicate indifference:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\succ_{b}: 1,2,4,3 \\
\succ_{b}: 3,1,2,4 \\
>_{I(b)}:[1,3],[2,4]
\end{gathered}
$$

Let $\phi$ be any unanimous matching mechanism. Every matching that is consistent with it must be unanimous. Under the truthful report for $b$, in any unanimous matching $\mu$, either $\mu(b)=1$ or $\mu(b)=3$. This implies that the worst-case scenario in any unanimous matching is that $b$ is matched to 3 . Under the report $\succ_{a}$ where $a$ reports only 1 as acceptable, $H^{*}(a)=\{1\}$. Therefore:

$$
C U^{-}\left[\succ_{b}\right]=\{(1,3)\}
$$

This implies that the worst-case under truth-telling is no better than $b$ matching to 3 . Consider a profile $\succ_{b}^{\prime}$ where $b$ reports the order $\succ_{b}^{\prime} ; 4,2,1$. Under this report, every home is unanimous except for 3 . Thus, in any unanimous matching $\mu^{\prime}$, either $\mu^{\prime}(b)=1$ or $\mu^{\prime}(b)=2$, or $\mu^{\prime}(b)=4$. The worst-case under $\succ_{b}^{\prime}$ must be better than 3 , so this manipulation is a worst-case manipulation.

Last, we prove (ii) in a general environment for any child $c$. It is immediate that the best case for $c$ under truthful reporting is going first in the order and matching to her top choice which is always unanimous. Under LE, she leaves the exchange and is permanently matched. Under SDI, we can stipulate preferences for all other $c^{\prime} \neq c$ such that $c$ 's top choice is unacceptable. Therefore, $c$ will also be matched to her top choice under SDI in the best-case scenario.

Suppose that $|H|<|C|$. The worst-case scenario under either mechanism, under any report, is that $c$ goes last and that every preceding child has a single top choice such that the set $H$ is covered by the children's top choices. In this case, $c$ is unmatched under either mechanism. If $|H|=|C|$, under any report, the same argument applies to show that $c$ is always matched to her least favorite home if $c$ 's report is such that all homes are unanimously acceptable and is unmatched if at least one home is not unanimously acceptable.

Proposition 6. The following statements are true:
i. $\tau^{u}$ is a strict total order,
ii. $\tau^{u}$ is regular, and
iii. If $\mu$ is constrained-efficient and unanimous, then $\mu$ is efficient under $\tau^{u}$.

Proof. First, we show that $\tau^{u}$ is a strict total order, i.e., that it is an element of $P$. Let the binary relation of $\tau^{u}$ be $T_{c}^{u}$. We omit $c$ and simply consider an arbitrary $c$ for this part.

Irreflexive: If $T^{u}$ is not irreflexive, then there exists some $x \in H$ such that $x T^{u} x$. Clearly, it cannot be that $x$ is strictly preferred to itself on preferences nor evaluations. Furthermore, it cannot be that $x \in H^{*}$ and $h \notin H^{*}$.

Transitive: Suppose that for some $x, y, z$, we have that (i) $x T^{u} y$ and (ii) $y T^{u} z$. (i) implies that (a) $x$ is a unanimous improvement over $y$, (b) $x \in H^{*}$ and $y \notin H^{*}$, or (c) $x \succ y$. In case (a) or (b), $y \notin H^{*}$. Therefore, (ii) only if $y$ is a unanimous improvement over $z$. Hence, $z \notin H^{*}(c)$. In case (a), $x$ must also be a unanimous improvement over $z$ so that $x T^{*} z$. In case (b), immediately $x T^{u} z$. In case (c), if $x \in H^{-}$then $y \in H^{-}$and (ii) only if $z \in H^{-}$and $y \succ z$, hence $x \succ z$ by assumption that $\succ \in P$. If $x \in H^{*}$ and $y \in H^{*}$, then the same holds if $z \in H^{*}$. If $z \notin H^{*}$, then immediately $x T^{u} z$.

Asymmetry: This follows by irreflexivity and transitivity.
Connected: All homes are comparable by definition.
Since only unanimously acceptable homes are acceptable under $\tau^{u}$, it cannot be that any unanimously acceptable home is not acceptable or that any unanimously unacceptable home is acceptable. Furthermore, suppose that $x \succ y$ and $x>y$ for any $x, y \in H$. It cannot be that $y \in H^{*}$. If $x \in H^{*}$, then $x T^{u} y$. If $x \notin H^{*}$, then still $x T^{u} y$ by definition and transitivity. These facts imply that the rule satisfies the WPP.

Last, we prove that if $\mu$ is constrained-efficient and unanimous, then $\mu$ is efficient under $\tau^{u}$. Suppose, for a contradiction, that $\mu$ is constrained-efficient and unanimous, but $\mu$ is not $\tau^{u}$-efficient. There must exist some $\tau^{u}$-improving cycle $\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \ldots, c_{n}\right)$ such

that $\mu\left(c_{i+1}\right) R_{v_{i}}^{u} \mu\left(c_{i}\right)$ for all $i \neq n$ and $\mu\left(c_{1}\right) R_{v_{n}}^{u} \mu\left(c_{n}\right)$ with at least one strict relation. However, this implies that any child that is assigned to a unanimous home is reassigned to another unanimous home that is a Pareto improvement. Any child that is assigned to a non-unanimous home is reassigned to another non-unanimous home that is a Pareto improvement. Otherwise, if a child at a non-unanimous home improves to a unanimous home, this contradicts $\mu$ being unanimous. The reassignment will therefore have the same unanimous coalition and will Pareto dominate $\mu$, which contradicts $\mu$ being constrainedefficient.

Proposition A.1. Random Serial Assignment is strategy proof when ignoring feasibility constraints.

Proof. We prove this by counterexample. Denote the true preferences for $c$ as $\succ_{c}$ (with corresponding problem $L$ ). Suppose that for some manipulation $\succ_{c}^{\prime}$ (with corresponding problem $\left.L^{\prime}\right), \phi_{R S A}\left[L^{\prime}\right](c) \succ_{c} \phi_{R S A}[L](c)$. Then in some round $n$, under $L^{\prime}$, RSA selects some $h^{\prime}$ that $c$ prefers over the $h$ selected (or not selected) in the same round $n$ under $L$. However, if $h^{\prime}$ is not selected under $L$, then $a\left(h^{\prime}\right)=0$. Therefore, it could not be selected under $L^{\prime}$. This proves the Proposition.

Proposition A.2. Truth-telling is the unique, non-trivial weakly dominant strategy under Random Serial Assignment when ignoring feasibility constraints.

Proof. In qualifying the proof with non-trivial, we make the assumption that every $c$ has at least one acceptable home. Under any manipulation $\succ_{c}^{\prime}, c$ either ranks some $h^{\prime}$ higher than some $h$ such that $h \succ_{c} h^{\prime}$ or $c$ reports some $h$ as unacceptable. In the latter case, it is clear that if $a(h)=1$ and $a\left(h^{\prime \prime}\right)=0$ for all $h^{\prime \prime} \neq h$, then this manipulation is strictly worse than truth-telling. In the former case, suppose that, (a) for every $h^{\prime \prime}$ such that $h^{\prime \prime} \succ_{c} h, a\left(h^{\prime \prime}\right)=0$, (b) $a\left(h^{\prime}\right)=1$, and (c) $a(h)=1$, then under the manipulation $h \succ_{c} \phi_{R S A}\left[L^{\prime}\right](c)$, but under truth-telling $\phi_{R S A}[L](c)=h$. Since there is always some case where a misreport is strictly worse than truth-telling, truth-telling must be the only unique weakly dominant strategy under the non-triviality assumption. This proves the Proposition.

# B Experiment Details 

We provide additional detail on our experiment in this section.

## Optimal Sample Size Analysis

Calculating the effects of our mechanisms requires computing matchings for many markets under them. Caseworker preferences are necessary to do this. We fill in caseworker preferences with a plausible hypothesis-race-based matching. Anecdotally, we are aware that caseworkers in some counties use race as a criteria to attempt to match a child to a culturally relevant home. LaBrenz et al. (2022) used an IPW regression model to estimate the effects of race-based matching. When the assumptions of the model hold, they show it has a positive impact on persistence. Concretely, we assume that given some market $m$, the foster home $h$ has a parent with the same race as the child $c$ and the foster home $h^{\prime}$ does not, then $h \succ_{c} h^{\prime}$. Otherwise, $h \sim h^{\prime}$. We further assume that all homes are acceptable.

Table B.1: Mechanism Performance under Race-Based Preferences

![table_9](table_9)

We generate one-hundred small markets as in the experimental design assuming these preferences. Our initial finding is promising. All mechanisms substantially increase persistence: SDI by 11.6 pp relative to SD while UTTC and LE increase by 13.4 pp relative to SD.

Next, we run robustness checks for the case where the algorithm has prediction error. We randomly perturb the persistence $Y_{c}(h)$. We flip a weighted coin that is one with probability 0.83 (the out-of-sample accuracy for our ML model) and zero otherwise. If the coin returns zero, then we set $Y_{c}(h)=1-\hat{Y}_{c}(h)$. Otherwise, $Y_{c}(h)=\hat{Y}_{c}(h)$. We reconduct the analysis above with these outcomes. The results are reported in Table B.2. We find that the positive welfare effects of our mechanisms are smaller in magnitude but still sizeable.

Table B.2: Mechanism Performance under Race-Based Preferences, Robust

![table_10](table_10)

Finally, we use this sample to conduct our optimal sample size analysis. We run one hundred simulations where we randomly keep $N$ observations for Serial Dictatorship and the mechanism in comparison in the sample and re-calculate the treatment effect, noting the significance and magnitude of the coefficient. We run these simulations for $N \in\{25,50,75\}$. Our simulations show that the coefficient sizes remain close, on average, to the same as in Table B.1. For $N=25,52 \%, 57 \%$, and $53 \%$ of the coefficient estimates were significant for SDI, UTTC, and LE, respectively. This jumps to $82 \%, 98 \%$, and $95 \%$ at $N=50$ and $100 \%$ for all at $N=75$.

abstract:
We study the problem of an organization that matches agents to objects where
agents have preference rankings over objects and the organization uses
algorithms to construct a ranking over objects on behalf of each agent. Our new
framework carries the interpretation that the organization and its agents may
be misaligned in pursuing some underlying matching goal. We design matching
mechanisms that integrate agent decision-making and the algorithm by avoiding
matches that are unanimously disagreeable between the two parties. Our
mechanisms also satisfy restricted efficiency properties. Subsequently, we
prove that no unanimous mechanism is strategy-proof but that ours can be
non-obviously manipulable. We generalize our framework to allow for any
preference aggregation rules and extend the famed Gibbard-Satterthwaite Theorem
to our setting. We apply our framework to place foster children in foster homes
to maximize welfare. Using a machine learning model that predicts child welfare
in placements and a (planned) novel lab-in-the-field eliciting real
caseworkers' preferences, we empirically demonstrate that there are important
match-specific welfare gains that our mechanisms extract that are not realized
under the status quo.
